sentence: In recent years, the “cloud” has emerged as one of the major focus area for technology giants such as Microsoft, Amazon, Google and IBM among other players.
“By 2020, a corporate "no-cloud" policy will be as rare as a "no-internet" policy is today,” according to Gartner.
Cloud can simply be thought of as the Internet.
With cloud, instead of maintaining on-premises data centers with computer hardware and software, companies can access all systems on the cloud platform of the service provider.

“Cloud computing is a model for enabling ubiquitous, convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (e.g., networks, servers, storage, applications, and services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service provider interaction” as explained by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).
Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS) and Software as a Service (SaaS) are the three offerings which can either be on a public, private or hybrid cloud.

While cloud computing services have been offered for more than a decade, companies were initially skeptical about such offerings amid concerns of sharing sensitive records and security of company’s data.

However, with its advantages such as flexibility, cutting of capital expenditure, easy anytime-anywhere access, disaster recovery, no fear of lost devices and opportunity for smaller enterprises to use infrastructure which cannot be afforded in-house, all started to attract enterprises to the cloud.

It is estimated that, “The savings created by a flexible infrastructure can be substantial, between 25% and 50% in federal agencies studied by the Brookings Institute.”

Gartner estimates that, “the IT spending is steadily shifting from traditional IT offerings to cloud services (cloud shift).

The aggregate amount of cloud shift in 2016 is estimated to reach $111 billion, increasing to $216 billion in 2020.” It is further estimated that “more than $1 trillion in IT spending will be directly or indirectly affected by the shift to cloud during the next five years.”
• Amazon (AMZN)'s Amazon Web Services (AWS) is the undisputed market leader in cloud computing.
It dominated the worldwide public IaaS with a 45% market share while it held about 35% of public PaaS during Q3 FY 2016.
It generated $3.2 billion in revenue for AWS during Q3 FY 2016.
• Microsoft (MSFT) has been highly focused on the cloud since Satya Nadella took over the reins at Microsoft.
The company plans to realize $20 billion as commercial cloud annualized revenue run rate by 2018; the same was reported at $12.1 billion during FY 2016.

• Cloud is an important component of IBM's (IBM) “strategic imperatives.” During Q3 2016, IBM’s cloud revenue (public, private and hybrid) increased 44% to $3.4 billion while its cloud revenue over the trailing 12 months was $12.7 billion.
• Google (GOOG, GOOGL) ranks among the top five cloud players with a worldwide market share of 4% according to SG Research.

In November 2015, Urs Hölzle, Senior Vice President for Technical Infrastructure at Google said, “My goal is for us to talk about Google as a cloud company in 2020 because our revenue is bigger than the ads revenue and it’s a realistic possibility.”
• Salesforce (CRM) is featured among the most innovative companies in the world and earns majority of its revenue from cloud computing.
It offers cloud services with a focus on CRM – Customer Relationship Management.
While Salesforce is a top CRM vendor accounting for 20% market share, its cloud services make up 4% of the overall market share.
• Adobe (ADBE) Creative Cloud offers innovative tools and services for creating digital media, data-driven marketing and more.

During the recently released earnings executive vice president and chief financial officer Mark Garrett said, “We are uniquely positioned as a cloud provider to deliver both top line and bottom line growth.” Adobe marketing cloud achieved $1.63 billion in annual revenue, 20% year-on-year growth.
• Oracle (ORCL) offers cloud services across all three service models i.e.
SaaS, PaaS and IaaS.

As per its earnings report, “Oracle is the number one player in SaaS cloud applications sales to customers with over 1,000 employees.” During Q2 FY 2017, its total cloud revenue increased 62% to touch $1.1 billion in revenue.
• Alibaba (BABA) considers cloud computing as its future growth areas.
Although its revenue from cloud remains small in absolute terms, it increased 130% year-on-year to $224 million during Q2 FY 2016.

Other companies such as SAP, Rackspace, NTT Communications, Fujitsu, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), workday, VMware (VMW), CISCO (CSCO) are also a part of the competitive cloud computing conglomerate .
Companies, both big and small have been investing heavily to acquire or establish data centers to cater to the growing demand for cloud in the coming times.
In September, IBM opened its 48th global cloud data center.
In October, Microsoft announced that it has more than doubled its cloud capacity in Europe in the past year, taking its investments in Europe over $3 billion to date.

While during the recent earnings call, Sundar Pichai, CEO, Google said, "And as we head into 2017, I expect cloud to be one of our largest areas of investment and headcount growth.”

Alibaba is not far behind, the company has announced four new data centers -- located in Japan, Germany, the Middle East and Australia, which will bring Alibaba Cloud’s worldwide total to 14.
There lies immense scope for growth in cloud computing with adoption levels remain low.

As per Google’s official blog, “In fact, only a tiny fraction of the world’s data is currently in the cloud – most businesses and applications aren’t cloud-based yet.” To combat the stiff completion and global increase in demand in times ahead, cloud computing providers are gearing by working on innovative solutions driven by machine learning and artificial intelligence, and enhanced security system on the cloud.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
